a.span: An announcement from NECSD Board President Carole Mineo and Superintendent Roberto Padilla (Click to Expand)

div.img:
We regret to inform our community of the passing of Ms. Sue Prokosch.
Sue has been a member of the NECSD Board of Education for nearly 10 years, most recently serving as its Vice-President. Sue also taught in our district educating our scholars for over 40 years. Sue was a strong advocate for education in our community and a champion for underprivileged children and those with high needs. Her commitment to our scholars, faculty, and staff will be greatly missed for years to come.
Sue began teaching social studies at North Junior High in the Newburgh Enlarged City School District in 1970 and retired in 2003. During her time as a teacher, she also worked with students in the Student Assistance Center. After retiring, Sue was elected to serve on the Board of Education four times, beginning in July 2010. She served as Board Vice President for five of those years. Throughout her time on the board, she served on almost every board committee and was mostly recently the Chairperson for the Buildings & Grounds and Personnel committees.
Sue made an amazing impact in this community and we ask that you keep her family and friends in your thoughts and prayers. During this tough time we will remember the service that Sue gave to our community, while continuing to be resilient during this difficult time as that is what Sue would have wanted.
With Condolences,
Carole Mineo & Roberto Padilla

br.button: April 7, 2020 - Letter from the Supt for Seniors

br.br:
Dearest Seniors,
How are you doing? Schools across New York were closed under orders by the Governor in an effort to stop the spread of Covid - 19. Yesterday, Governor Cuomo announced that school buildings will remain closed until April 29th, 2020. Based on trends across the country, it is very likely we will continue to get extended.
This afternoon, the NYS Board of Regents released guidance on Regents exams. June 2020 Regents exams are officially cancelled. Please give your administration, teachers, and school counselors this week to unpack this guidance. You can call them and/or participate in the newly established virtual office hours with specific questions. We understand the uncertainty of these times and the impact it's having on our seniors.
Furthermore, we understand this is a time of year when you would have been performing in your last concert, acting in your last play, competing in your last athletic event, finalizing prom details, and preparing to walk across Academy Field. This is why we are launching a campaign in our district called #SavetheSeniorExperience. We are committed to ensuring you and your family have your memorable, in-person graduation. As soon as we get through this, we will celebrate you as seniors. Until we get the clearance to return, we will send you videos of encouragement, will call you to check in, update you on scholarship and FAFSA deadlines, and share opportunities to connect with your teachers and peers.
Since we are not in the buildings, we have extended the yearbook order date. The yearbook must be ordered online at this site ybpay.lifetouch.com. The code you need to enter is 12906820. Please order your book now to be sure you are able to get one this year. Don't forget to order yours today! The link will be open until April 16, 2020.
Finally, I know that it is hard to look beyond this immediate time period, but life will not be like this forever and you still need to focus on your future. Don't forget that the deadline to submit scholarship applications is this Monday (April 13th). Visit www.newburghschools.org/scholarships for more information. While you're there, check out the other scholarships as well.
We will get through this together. For now, stay focused, stay positive, and complete your assigned work so we can prepare for your graduation. New instruction starts on Monday, April 13th. For more information about #SavetheSeniorExperience follow me on Twitter @NewburghSup. We miss you!
ShoulderingUp for You,
Roberto Padilla, Ed.D
Superintendent of School

br.button: April 2, 2020 - Letter from the Supt for Families

br.br:
Dear NECSD families,
Thank you! We appreciate your partnership and understanding during these challenging times. I hope that you and your family are remaining physically healthy as a first priority. For those in our community who have been directly impacted by COVID-19, we will continue to keep you in our thoughts and try our best to assist your family. Please reach out if you or members of your family need support. We want to continue to be here for you in whatever ways we can. In our ongoing effort to provide our school community with accurate, timely and consistent messaging, I am sharing additional information relating to the ongoing Coronavirus (COVID-19) public health crisis.
The Governor’s newest executive order (200.11), required the cancellation of Spring recess, scheduled for April 6-10. All schools in New York are mandated to continue online instruction without interruption. We, like you, are disappointed that we are unable to provide a much-needed and well-earned break for scholars, teachers, and families. As a result of this mandate, the following calendar will go into effect:
April 6 - April 10
This is an additional week to make up work and/or complete work that teachers assign. The last day to submit work for the 3rd quarter will be April 10th.
April 13th
The fourth quarter begins and new instruction/content will be taught.
April 20th
Report cards will be provided digitally.
While our buildings are closed, the spirit and the essence of our schools is very much alive. I am so grateful to be in a district with such dedicated faculty and staff who are committed to keeping our schools running - even if they are operating differently than we are used to.
A new NECSD Guidance Plan for continuity of instruction with enrichment and student services will be available by tomorrow. The guidance plan will include, but is not limited to:
Online schedules for students
Grading guidelines for the 4th quarter
Attendance requirements and procedures
Thank you again for your kind, supportive words. Together, we will get through this pandemic. If we can be of any further assistance, please do not hesitate to reach out to your child’s teacher, principal, or myself. Best wishes for continued health and safety.
With Appreciation,
Roberto Padilla, Ed.D
Superintendent of Schools
Queridas Familias del NECSD,
¡Gracias! Agradecemos su colaboración y comprensión durante estos tiempos difíciles. Espero que usted y su familia se mantengan físicamente saludables como primera prioridad. Para aquellos en nuestra comunidad que han sido directamente afectados por COVID-19, continuaremos manteniéndolo en nuestros pensamientos y haremos nuestro mejor esfuerzo para ayudar a su familia. No dude en comunicarse con nosotros si usted o los miembros de su familia necesitan apoyo. Queremos seguir estando aquí para usted de cualquier manera que podamos. En nuestro esfuerzo continuo por proporcionar a nuestra comunidad escolar mensajes precisos, oportunos y consistentes, comparto información adicional relacionada con la actual crisis de salud pública de Coronavirus (COVID-19).
La nueva orden ejecutiva del gobernador (200.11), requirió la cancelación del receso de primavera, programado del 6 al 10 de abril. Todas las escuelas en Nueva York tienen el mandato de continuar la instrucción en línea sin interrupción. Nosotros, como usted, estamos decepcionados de que no podamos proporcionar un descanso muy necesario y bien ganado para los estudiantes, maestros y familias. Como resultado de este mandato, entrará en vigencia el siguiente calendario:
6 de abril - 10 de abril
Esta es una semana adicional para recuperar el trabajo y / o completar el trabajo que los maestros asignan. El último día para enviar trabajos para el tercer trimestre será el 10 de abril.
13 de abril
Comienza el cuarto trimestre y se enseñará nueva instrucción / contenido.
20 de abril
Las boletas de calificaciones se proporcionarán digitalmente.
Mientras nuestros edificios están cerrados, el espíritu y la esencia de nuestras escuelas están muy vivos. Estoy muy agradecido de estar en un distrito con una facultad y personal tan dedicados que se comprometen a mantener nuestras escuelas funcionando, incluso aunque funcionan de manera diferente a lo que estamos acostumbrados.
Mañana estará disponible un nuevo Plan de Orientación NECSD para la continuidad de la instrucción con enriquecimiento y servicios estudiantiles. El plan de orientación incluirá, pero no se limitará a:
Horarios en línea para estudiantes
Pautas de calificaciones para el cuarto trimestre
Requisitos y procedimientos de asistencia.
Gracias nuevamente por sus amables palabras de apoyo. Juntos, superaremos esta pandemia. Si podemos brindarle más ayuda, no dude en comunicarse con el maestro, el director o yo mismo de su hijo. Los mejores deseos para la salud y seguridad de todos.
Con apreciación,
Roberto Padilla, Ed.D
Superintendente de Escuelas

br.button: March 31, 2020 - Letter from the Supt for Staff

br.br:
Dear Beloved Faculty & Staff,
This communication serves several purposes. I can't say thank you enough. I sing your praises to other districts because you are models for others. You have demonstrated flexibility, patience, and great care for our scholars. We appreciate all that you are doing. The following information is the most recent guidance we have received from the Governor’s Office and the New York State Department of Education to date regarding school closures.
Based on the Governor’s newest executive order (200.11), Spring recess, scheduled for April 6-10, is cancelled. We are mandated to continue online instruction, from home, without interruption. We, like you, are disappointed that we are unable to provide a much-needed and well-earned break for scholars, teachers, and families. However, as a result of the latest Executive Order and clarification that we received from the New York State Department of Education (NYSED) today, all school districts are required to cancel spring break and continue virtual instruction. According to guidance issued by NYSED:
Districts must continue to provide remote instruction for students, meals for students, and child care for essential workers every weekday between April 1, 2020, and April 14, 2020.
Failure to comply with this Executive Order disqualifies Newburgh from receiving a waiver for completing the required 180 instructional days. Therefore, we must fully comply. The majority of our budget is comprised of state aid. The loss of state aid would result in a reduction of programs and staff. We cannot allow this to happen for failure to enforce the Executive Order. Accordingly, we all will continue to work remotely during the week of April 6th. We will extend makeup work opportunities for scholars all of next week that will be graded as part of the third quarter. The fourth quarter will begin April 13th.
A new NECSD Guidance Plan for continuity of instruction with enrichment and student services will be available by the end of this week. Beginning, April 13th, we will transition from skill review and reinforcement, to new instruction and content. The guidance plan will include, but is not limited to:
teaching and learning schedules
grading guidelines for the 4th quarter
permitted video conference platforms
faculty/staff start & end times
The Board of Education and I acknowledge, respect and understand how you consistently ShoulderUp when it is needed the most. While we are directed to continue distance learning, we are grateful that our scholars have you!
Goldack Nation is an incredibly resilient community. Let’s continue to stay positive. We will all get through this together.
Thank you.
Through the Work of All,
Roberto Padilla, Ed.D
Superintendent of Schools
× Close

Dear Families, Faculty, and Staff,
I miss you! I hope that you are in good spirits and good health. As we enter our second week of learning from home, I have been encouraged by the creativity and innovation of our entire school community. Day after day, I see a plethora of examples of our mantra in action, ShoulderUp. Our faculty and staff have approached this new reality of learning with excitement, energy and a true Goldback commitment to finding a rhythm and routine remotely.
I write in a time of extraordinary global crisis, but also in a time of extraordinary opportunity. In our district, like so many others, schools have been closed and we have moved to online education for the foreseeable future. The good news is that our faculty is doing the very best they can and deeply care about their students. This is evident in their actions.
Teachers are providing virtual office hours and organizing activities remotely. One teacher shared how she successfully flipped her classroom, another teacher highlighted how she got 90% of students online via Google Meet. She brimmed with excitement as students shared how much they missed each other. I recently watched a Kindergarten student from New Windsor School share the learning that was taking place at home and how much he missed his teachers and classmates. These stories and so many others are a few examples of how our community is coming together. It’s not perfect, but I know everyone is trying their best. Just think, Covid – 19 took hold quickly and school districts had to quickly adapt. I am proud of all of you.
As this week unfolds, administrators, teachers, staff and students are learning together, listening to one another, adjusting pace and workload. I encourage you to continue this level of collaboration. Collaboration is the “C” in our NECSD core values! Our faculty are spending endless hours communicating, planning, and innovating. The connection between teacher and student is stronger than ever.
Your principals, teachers, Board of Education and I appreciate every note, message, and email we receive from our parents and our scholars. Hang in there, we will get through this together.
Ongoing Communication
I will attempt to provide a weekly update to faculty, staff, and families about recent decisions made at state and/or federal levels. We will be mindful about how much information gets pushed out as everyone may become overloaded with information. We are committed to streamlining outreach. Except under extraordinary circumstances, you will receive two communications per week from me.
While schools are closed, I will send a districtwide update every Thursday. Your child’s principal may also communicate school-based information. We encourage you to regularly visit our district website and our social media pages are updated frequently. Two recently added resources are SAT tutoring, and updates from NYSED on state testing.
**NEW NECSD Virtual Learning Hub
Our District is committed to serving our community. Please refer to our NECSD Virtual Learning Hub for learning from home resources during this time of school closure. This will serve as the district’s go-to for academic support, best practices, training, and information for families.
Childcare and Supervision for Medical Professionals and First Responders
During this extraordinary crisis, the District is committed to serving our community. If you are a first responder; health care professional who has been deemed ‘essential staff’ by the governor, we can assist you in getting daycare. If you need assistance, please use our special hotline: 845-568-6533 and leave a message with as much detail as possible. You can also contact our Director of Family and Community Engagement, Ms. Pamela Peterson at ppeterson@necsd.net.
Social Distancing
Please adhere to and model social distancing. These requirements are meant to protect you. We know it may be hard, but the more we actually stay at home and follow these protocols, the sooner we can get back to school. This is for your protection and the protection of your family.
When we care for one another, we care for our entire community. I welcome your feedback and encourage you to reach out to me, your principal, or your child’s teacher. Be safe.
ShoulderUp,
Roberto Padilla
Superintendent

br.p: Dear Newburgh Enlarged City School District Families and Employees,

This afternoon, we were contacted by the Orange County Department of Health and were made aware that someone regularly at Heritage Middle School tested positive for COVID-19. March 13th is the last known date this individual was present at the school.
Anyone who was in Heritage Middle School on Friday, March 13th, 2020, and is symptomatic, should contact their healthcare provider.
Please understand, the person who has the infection will not be cleared to re-enter any district school buildings until the following occurs:
❑ Seven days has passed from the last test where the person has tested positive for the infection
❑ Two subsequent negative tests have occurred 24 hours apart.

There is no evidence that the disease is airborne. In order to be affected, all the evidence shows that the disease is droplet transmitted or transmitted by someone who, within hours after the infected person touched the same surface with some sort of bodily fluid (sneezing, runny nose, sweat) as the infected person caused that fluid to be on.

It has been emphasized for weeks that a community spread component is real and serious. In most cases of a community spread, symptomatic people are walking around and have no idea they are infected. Here on the other hand, we know of one person so people can at least be armed with the knowledge of what to look for.

The best way to prevent community spread of COVID-19 is to avoid groups, engage in social distancing, and be aware of anyone who appears sick. People who sense their own symptoms should contact their healthcare provider before just showing up at their doctor’s office.

During this time of extended closure, the District has been and will continue to actively assess and monitor all aspects of this rapidly changing situation in consultation with local, state and federal officials. We have been in regular contact with the Department of Health regarding any concerns that have been brought to our attention and we have followed their guidance throughout.

We understand this information is concerning. We are fully committed to our students, families, and thank all who have provided guidance and support to the district over the past week. This is a complex matter and we will continue to manage it with the same sense of purpose and sound leadership our students, staff and community deserve.

Be Safe,
Roberto Padilla, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools

Estimadas familias y empleados del Distrito escolar ampliado de la ciudad de Newburgh:
Esta tarde, fuimos contactados por el Departamento de Salud del Condado de Orange y nos informaron que alguien regularmente en el campus de Heritage Middle School dio positivo a COVID-19. El 13 de marzo es la última fecha conocida que este individuo estuvo presente en la escuela.
Cualquier persona que estuvo en el campus de Heritage Middle School el viernes 13 de Marzo de 2020 y tiene síntomas, debe comunicarse con su proveedor de atención médica.
Por favor comprenda, que la persona que tiene la infección no tendrá autorización para volver a ingresar a los edificios escolares del distrito hasta que ocurra lo siguiente:
Han pasado siete días desde la última prueba en la que la persona dio positivo por la infección.
Y
Dos pruebas negativas posteriores se produjeron con 24 horas de diferencia
No hay evidencia de que la enfermedad sea transmitida por el aire. Para ser afectado, toda la evidencia muestra que la enfermedad es transmitida por gotitas o transmitida por alguien que pocas horas después de que la persona infectada tocó la misma superficie con algún tipo de fluido corporal (estornudos, secreción nasal, sudor) ya que la persona infectada causó que ese líquido estuviera en esa superficie.
Se ha enfatizado durante semanas que un componente de difusión comunitaria es real y serio.En la mayoría de los casos de propagación comunitaria, las personas sintomáticas están caminando y no tienen idea de que están infectadas. Aquí, por un lado sabemos de una persona, y las personas pueden al menos estar armadas con el conocimiento de qué buscar.
La mejor manera de prevenir la propagación comunitaria de COVID-19 es evitar grupos, participar en el distanciamiento social y estar al tanto de cualquier persona que parezca enferma. Las personas que perciben sus propios síntomas deben comunicarse con su proveedor de atención médica antes de presentarse en el consultorio de su médico.
Durante este tiempo de cierre prolongado, el Distrito ha estado y continuará evaluando y monitoreando activamente todos los aspectos de esta situación que cambia rápidamente en consulta con funcionarios locales, estatales y federales.Hemos estado en contacto regular con el Departamento de Salud con respecto a cualquier inquietud que se nos haya señalado y hemos seguido su orientación en todo momento.
Entendemos que esta información es preocupante, Estamos totalmente comprometidos con nuestros estudiantes, familias, y agradezco a todos los que han brindado orientación y apoyo al distrito durante la semana pasada. Este es un asunto complejo y continuaremos manejándolo con el mismo sentido de propósito y liderazgo sólido que nuestros estudiantes, el personal y la comunidad merecen.
Cuidese,
Roberto Padilla, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools

br.p: Dear Newburgh Enlarged City School District Families,

Yesterday, Governor Cuomo signed an executive order to close all NYS schools for 14 days starting tomorrow, Wednesday, March 18th through Tuesday, March 31st. Schools are expected to open on April 1st, however, this may change when the state reassesses whether the mandated closure should be extended. The intention of this closure is to help mitigate the spread of the virus in our schools and community. As we navigate this uncertain and challenging situation, please take precautions to keep yourself and your family safe.

Tomorrow, Wednesday, March 18, 2020 school buildings will be open from 9am – 1pm for students, faculty, and staff to pick up personal belongings if necessary. You must contact your building principal via email ahead of time to receive an appointment time.

Starting Thursday, March 19, 2020, you should be receiving additional information about learning opportunities. Also, starting Thursday, teachers will begin offering virtual office hours from 9am - 1pm daily. Scholars should use email and/or Google Meet to correspond with their teachers.
All IEP meetings have been cancelled until further notice and will be rescheduled at a later date.

Through the work of all,
Roberto Padilla, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools
Newburgh Enlarged City School District

p.span: Dear Newburgh School District Families and Staff,

We greatly appreciate your continued flexibility and support in light of this national health pandemic. Please continue to take the essential precautions for you and your family. Today, New York State Governor Andrew Cuomo, through executive order the continuation of school closures. The intention of this closure is to help mitigate the spread of the virus in our schools and wider communities.

Additionally, as the details of the State and Federal strategy addressing the Coronavirus continue to emerge, their recommendations are likely to change. Therefore, families should prepare for the potential of longer school closures. As a result of this, we ask for your continued flexibility. Some of this flexibility will come in the form of calendar revisions. More information regarding any such changes will be shared in the future as our current priority is to focus on providing on-going learning opportunities, and supporting the well-being of our school community.

In the Newburgh Schools, we developed the plans outlined below to support our students’ learning while they are at home. Please be reminded that during the school closures, all athletic and extracurricular activities are canceled.

Our administrators, teachers and staff have been diligently preparing for school closures during this rapidly changing reality. The following information will help you plan as our District awaits additional guidance from New York State Governor’s office, New York State Department of Education, and the New York State Department of Health.

Dear NECSD families,
Together, we are facing an unprecedented health crisis in our communities. For weeks, we have been following the explicit guidance of the Orange County Department of Health and the New York State Department of Education, by implementing preventative and responsive strategies to help slow the spread of COVID-19, the novel coronavirus. The departments of health have been in daily contact with us, providing important guidance on decisions to help ensure the health and well-being of our scholars, employees, and community.
At this time, the Orange County Department of Health has not informed our district of any diagnosed cases of the coronavirus within our district, however, to prevent the further spread of this global pandemic and per the recommendation of Orange County Executive Steve Neuhaus, all schools within the Newburgh Enlarged City School District will be closed for a two week period, beginning Monday, March 16, 2020.
Our administrators and several groups of teachers have been working to prepare plans for the potential of an extended school closure. Please find some initial information below. More information will be forthcoming as we continue to navigate this unique time.
Meals:
A plan has been created for distribution of meals to our scholars. Beginning Tuesday, March 17, 2020, breakfast and lunch will be provided to each child under 18. If the student is enrolled in our schools and is over 19 they should bring their school ID. The locations and schedule are:

Plan for Continued Instruction:
Earlier today, Chromebooks and chargers were sent home with scholars in grades 3-12 in anticipation of a potential extended school closing. Pre-K, Kindergarten, Grade 1 and Grade 2 scholars will not have Chromebooks. More information regarding instructional materials for grades Pre-K-2 will be available on our district website and at the meal locations.
Our administrators, directors, and lead teachers have been working to create instructional resources and lessons that will be available for our scholars. Additionally, our Technology Department has been working to acquire 1,000 hotspots for those who do not have internet access at home. Additional information about that distribution process will be forthcoming.
Additional Support:
The Family and Community Engagement team has been working to create a toolkit of documents for families that will be distributed at meal sites. Additionally, a hotline has been set up with information regarding food distribution, online or hardcopy academic resources, information for our McKinney-Vento families, and general information.
The phone number for the Family and Community Engagement hotline is: 845-568-6533.
Through the work of all,
Roberto Padilla, Ed.D.

The school closures caused by Novel Coronavirus are unprecedented and so, the NYS Education Department has had to make unprecedented decisions for students across the state. The administrations of the 2020 elementary- and intermediate-level State assessments have been suspended for the remainder of this school year. This suspension for the remainder of the school year applies to the following New York State testing programs:
New York State Grades 3-8 English Language Arts Test;
New York State Grades 3-8 Mathematics Test;
New York State Grade 4 Elementary-Level Science Test;
New York State Grade 8 Intermediate-Level Science Test;
New York State English as a Second Language Achievement Test (NYSESLAT) in Grades K-12; and
New York State Alternate Assessment (NYSAA) for students with severe cognitive disabilities in Grades 3-8 and high school.

The health and safety of students and educators is our top priority. The College Board is closely monitoring the updates and guidance about the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and other leading health organizations. On Friday, March 13, 2020, The College Board launched a web page on AP Central to provide information about flexible testing options for schools experiencing substantial disruption or closure and guidance for schools that plan to maintain AP instruction while students are at home.
The AP Program has developing resources to help schools support student learning during extended closures, as well as a solution that would allow students to test at home, depending on the situation in May. Additionally, they have announced portfolio submission deadline extensions for AP 2-D Art and Design, 3-D Art and Design, Computer Science Principles, Drawing, Research, and Seminar courses by March 20. Schools do not need to call AP Services for Educators to request these extensions. This information can be found at: https://apcentral.collegeboard.org/about-ap/news-changes/coronavirus-update
Beginning on Wednesday, March 25, students and teachers can attend free, live AP review courses, delivered by AP teachers from across the country. The schedule for those courses and addition AP information can be found here: https://apstudents.collegeboard.org/coronavirus-updates#free-ap-classes. These mobile-friendly classes are:
Designed to be used alongside work that may be given by schools.
Will be recorded and available on-demand so teachers and students can access them any time.
Not dependent on current AP teachers continuing instruction. We know many AP teachers now face challenges that would make that impossible.
Will focus on reviewing the skills and concepts from the first 75% of the course. There will also be some supplementary lessons including topics from the final 25% of the course.

https://www.collegeboard.org/releases/2020/college-board-cancels-may-sat-response-coronavirus
In response to the rapidly evolving situation around the coronavirus (COVID-19), the College Board is canceling the May 2, 2020, SAT administration. Makeup exams for the March 14 administration (scheduled March 28) are also canceled. Registered students will receive refunds.
The College Board will provide future additional SAT testing opportunities for students as soon as feasible in place of canceled administrations. We’ll be as flexible as possible to give students the best chance to show their skills and stay on the path to college. We have not yet canceled the June 6, 2020, SAT administration and will continue to assess its status with the health and safety of students and educators as our top priority. The College Board is working with local partners, and we’ll soon share information about weekday school-based administrations this spring of the SAT, PSAT 10, and PSAT 8/9.
To help students keep their college readiness skills sharp when many schools are closed, the College Board and Khan Academy will continue to provide free resources online, including full-length practice tests and personalized learning tools at khanacademy.org/sat. As a reminder, you can set up coaching tools in Khan for teachers to monitor student work. For more information on the coaching tools, visit satpractice.org/k12. If you need assistance setting this up, please reach out.
Together with our member schools and colleges, we will be flexible, thoughtful, and collaborative in exploring ways to continue to support student learning and provide opportunities to test during this challenging time.
In the coming days, the College Board will share additional information and details directly with registered students and test centers. A webpage with regularly posted information about the impact of the virus on the SAT can be found here.

The last day for payment to the school tax office is Tuesday, March 31st. We encourage you to use our online payment portal at www.infotaxonline.com. Electronic check (e-check) is $1.50 per transaction. Credit/debit cards have a 2.65% convenience fee ($3 minimum).
At the search screen enter in ONLY your BILL NUMBER
If you do not know your bill number, enter in the STREET NUMBER and NAME ONLY - do NOT enter in the type of street.
If the search fails, please clear the search criteria before trying again. All fields in blue can be clicked for instructions regarding that field.
Click "Pay Balance" tab, then choose "Pay Installment Due" or "Pay Taxes in Full" Payment defaults to credit/debit card, you must click the "Pay with e-check" tab for electronic checks. Continue by providing your card or banking information. Click "Next" to submit your payment.
Payments can still be mailed to the tax office but must be legally postmarked on or before March 31st. We recommend a hand-stamp at a local post office if possible.
All unpaid installments have penalties due, please add the appropriate amount when remitting your payment.
1st installment has a 6% penalty
2nd installment has a 4% penalty
3rd installment has a 1% penalty.
However, we encourage you to use our website – www.infotaxonline.com to see the exact amount due. At your parcel information screen, click the "Payment Schedule" tab.
If you normally make a cash payment at our office, you will need to get a money order or bank check made payable to NECSD. Mail it to NECSD Tax Office, 124 Grand Street, Newburgh, NY 12550.
If you need further assistance, you can email the tax collector at cpinter@necsd.net.
